API Reference¶

Streams¶

These are all the available Streams, implementing subscribers, publishers/timers etc.

template<typename _Value, typename _ErrorValue = Nothing, typename Derived = Nothing>
class Stream : public icey::StreamTag¶

An stream. Similar to a promise in JavaScript.

Subclassed by icey::InterpolateableStream< geometry_msgs::msg::TransformStamped, TransformSubscriptionStreamImpl >

Public Types

using promise_type = Self¶

Ok, let’s go: First, we are a promise:

Public Functions

template<typename F>
inline auto then(F &&f)¶

Creates a new Stream that changes it’s value to y every time the value x of the parent stream changes, where y = f(x).

template<class T, typename ...Args>
inline void publish(Args&&... args)¶

Create a ROS publisher by creating a new stream of type T and connecting it to this stream.

template<class O, typename ...Args>
inline auto create_stream(Args&&... args)¶

TODO use this, perfect FW.

inline auto timeout(rclcpp::Duration max_age, bool create_extra_timer = true)¶

TODO document.

inline void publish(const std::string &topic_name, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::SystemDefaultsQoS())¶

Create a ROS normal publisher.

template<class ServiceT>
inline auto call_service(const std::string &service_name, const Duration &timeout, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::ServicesQoS())¶

Create a new ServiceClient stream, this stream holds the request.

inline auto unpack()¶

Unpacks an Stream holding a tuple as value to multiple Streams for each tuple element.

inline std::suspend_never initial_suspend()¶

Third, we never already got something since this is a stream (we always first need to spin the ROS executor to get a message), so we never suspend:

inline Value return_value()¶

Fourth, we return_value returns the value of the promise:

template<class T>
inline void return_value(const T &x) const¶

Fifth, if the return_value function is called with a value, it sets the value, makes sense right ? No ? Oh .. (Reference: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20210330-00/?p=105019)

inline void unhandled_exception()¶

Sixth, we already handle exceptions in the promise.

inline std::suspend_never final_suspend() const noexcept¶

Seventh, we do not need to do anything at the end, no extra cleanups needed.

template<class ReturnType>
inline auto await_transform(ReturnType x)¶

Eight, promisify a value if needed, meaning if it is not already a promise and set context since we need to have the executor

inline void spin_executor()¶

Spin the event loop, (the ROS executor) until this Promise is fulfilled.

inline bool await_ready()¶

Now the Awaiter interface for C++20 coroutines: Do we have a value ?

inline bool await_suspend(auto)¶

Spin the ROS event loop until we got a value.

inline auto await_resume()¶

Consume the result and return it.

template<class NewVal, class NewErr>
inline Stream<NewVal, NewErr> create_from_impl(const std::shared_ptr<impl::Stream<NewVal, NewErr, WithDefaults<Nothing>, WithDefaults<Nothing>>> &impl) const¶

Pattern-maching factory function that creates a New Self with different value and error types based on the passed implementation pointer. (this is only needed for impl::Stream::done, which creates a new stream that always has Derived stripped off, i.e. set to Nothing.)

template<typename _Value>
struct ParameterStream : public icey::Stream<_Value, Nothing, ParameterStreamImpl<_Value>>¶

An stream for ROS parameters. Fires initially an event if a default_value set.

Public Functions

inline ParameterStream(NodeBookkeeping &node, const std::string &parameter_name, const std::optional<_Value> &default_value, const Validator<_Value> &validator = Validator<_Value>(), std::string description = "", bool read_only = false, bool ignore_override = false)¶

A more traditional constructor.

inline const _Value &value() const¶

Parameters are initialized always at the beginning, so they always have a value.

inline operator _Value() const¶

Allow implicit conversion to the stored value type for consistent API between constrained and non-constrained parameters when using the parameter structs.

NOLINT

template<typename _Message>
struct SubscriptionStream : public icey::Stream<_Message::SharedPtr>¶

A stream that represents a regular ROS subscriber. It stores as its value always a shared pointer to the message.

Public Functions

inline SubscriptionStream(NodeBookkeeping &node, const std::string &topic_name, const rclcpp::QoS &qos, const rclcpp::SubscriptionOptions &options)¶

Needed for synchronizer to determine message type.

template<typename _Value>
struct PublisherStream : public icey::Stream<_Value, Nothing, PublisherImpl<_Value>>¶
template<typename _ServiceT>
struct ServiceStream : public icey::Stream<std::pair<std::shared_ptr<_ServiceT::Request>, std::shared_ptr<_ServiceT::Response>>>¶

A service stream, storing it’s request and response.

Warning

doxygenstruct: Cannot find class “icey::ClientStream” in doxygen xml output for project “icey” from directory: .build/doxygenxml/

Warning

doxygenstruct: Cannot find class “icey::ClientStreamImpl” in doxygen xml output for project “icey” from directory: .build/doxygenxml/

Filters¶

The following filters handle synchronization, serialization timeout and other operations on streams.

template<class _Message>
struct TF2MessageFilter : public icey::Stream<_Message::SharedPtr, std::string, TF2MessageFilterImpl<_Message>>¶

Wrapper for the tf2_ros::MessageFilter.

template<typename _Value>
struct TimeoutFilter : public icey::Stream<_Value, std::tuple<rclcpp::Time, rclcpp::Time, rclcpp::Duration>>¶

FW declarations for Streams that we can create.

A filter that detects timeouts on different topics. It does so by creating an extra timer TODO assert message has a header stamp. TODO allow parameters as max_age

ROS-related¶

template<typename _Value>
struct TimeoutFilter : public icey::Stream<_Value, std::tuple<rclcpp::Time, rclcpp::Time, rclcpp::Duration>>

FW declarations for Streams that we can create.

A filter that detects timeouts on different topics. It does so by creating an extra timer TODO assert message has a header stamp. TODO allow parameters as max_age

Context¶

The context is responsible for

class Context : public std::enable_shared_from_this<Context>¶

The context owns the streams.

Public Functions

template<class O, typename ...Args>
inline auto create_stream(Args&&... args)¶

Creates a new stream of type O by passing the args to the constructor. It adds the impl to the list of streams so that it does not go out of scope. It also sets the context

template<typename ServiceT>
inline auto create_client(const std::string &service_name, const Duration &timeout, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::ServicesQoS())¶

Add a service client.

template<typename ServiceT, typename Parent>
inline auto create_client(Parent parent, const std::string &service_name, const Duration &timeout, const rclcpp::QoS &qos = rclcpp::ServicesQoS())¶

Add a service client and connect it to the parent.

Public Static Functions

template<class Reference, class ...Interpolatables>
static inline auto sync_with_reference(Reference reference, Interpolatables... interpolatables)¶

Synchronizer that given a reference signal at its first argument, ouputs all the other topics.

template<typename ...Parents>
static inline auto synchronize_approx_time(Parents... parents)¶

Synchronizer that synchronizes non-interpolatable signals by matching the time-stamps approximately

template<typename ...Parents>
static inline auto synchronize(Parents... parents)¶

Synchronize a variable amount of Streams. Uses a Approx-Time synchronizer if the inputs are not interpolatable or an interpolation-based synchronizer based on a given (non-interpolatable) reference. Or, a combination of both, this is decided at compile-time.

template<typename ...Parents>
static inline auto serialize(Parents... parents)¶

Serialize, pipe arbitrary number of parents of the same type into one. Needed for the control-flow where the same publisher can be called from multiple callbacks

C++20’ coroutines support¶
